WAY TO GO!

Fields.Title: AAR1-2a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $arthur eq "Insider trading and money laundering.">>
<<display "AAR1-2c">>
<<else>>
<<display "AAR1-2b">>

Fields.Title: AAR1-2b
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: <<print $arthur>>.]

Remember Terry's question about Arthur Flaherty... that she wondered what he might be mixed up in? 

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

TERRY
What are you up to, Arthur Flaherty...? 

[ENDCLIP]|

Since Terry had suggested that Arthur had shady partners and seemed to do way better than the market on his stock picks, insider trading and money laundering might seem likely. But here's the key: [em2]the probability of two events occurring together is always lower than the probability of either event occurring individually[/em2], even if the two combined events seem more representative of the person or situation. 

You avoided the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1] since you thought that it was more likely that Flaherty was guilty of a single crime than two crimes together. Great job!! 

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-2d]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2c
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: <<print $arthur>>.]

Remember Terry's question about Arthur Flaherty...that she wondered what he might be mixed up in? 

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

TERRY
What are you up to, Arthur Flaherty...? 

[ENDCLIP]|

The choices were all pretty plausible -- but your choice (insider trading and money laundering) reflected the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1]. 

Can you think of why?

<<User Input>>
I should not have considered Terry's speculation about Arthur.  [GO TO AAR1-2c1]
My choice listed two crimes. [GO TO AAR1-2c2]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2c1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Actually, your initial answer cited two kinds of crimes -- insider trading and money laundering -- which might have seemed likely since Terry suggested that Arthur had shady partners and seemed to do way better than the market on his stock picks. 

But here’s the key: [em2]the probability of two events occurring together is always lower than the probability of either event occurring individually[/em2], even if the two combined events seem more representative of the person or situation. To avoid the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1], remember that similarity does not trump pure probability.  

[GO TO AAR1-2d]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2c2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
That's right! Your initial answer cited two kinds of crimes -- insider trading and money laundering -- which might have seemed likely since Terry suggested that Arthur had shady partners and seemed to do way better than the market on his stock picks.

To avoid the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1], remember that similarity does not trump pure probability.  

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-2d]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2d
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Try this one:

Suppose, in the next Wimbledon, the world's number two-ranked men's professional tennis player reaches the finals. Do you think it is more likely that:

<<User Input>>
The player will lose the first set.      [GO TO AAR1-2d2]
The player will lose the first set but win the match.    [GO TO AAR1-2d3]
The player will win the first set but lose the match.    [GO TO AAR1-2d4]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2d2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "The player will lose the first set," is unbiased!]

I think you've got it! You remembered that the probability of two events happening together is always lower than either event occurring individually. 

You avoided the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1]– great job!!

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2d3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "The player will lose the first set but win the match."]

Your answer is not quite right. Assuming that two outcomes happening together (losing the first set AND winning the match) is more likely than either outcome happening alone is an example of the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1]. 

[em2]Remember: the probability of two events happening together is always lower than either event occurring individually.[/em2]

[GO TO AAR1-2e]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2d4
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "The player will win the first set but lose the match.”]

Your answer is not quite right. Assuming that two outcomes happening together (winning the first set AND losing the match) is more likely than either outcome happening alone is an example of the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1]. 

[em2]Remember: the probability of two events happening together is always lower than either event occurring individually.[/em2]

[GO TO AAR1-2e]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2e
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Here's another (fictional) example. Wade Fleese is a wise-cracking, down-to-earth politico who's always ready for a beer and a chat with his constituents, who in turn elected him mayor by a solid margin. Mayor Fleese's popularity plunged, however, when an online video surfaced showing Fleese stumbling drunk from a bar and getting behind the wheel of his Buick. The Buick was later found neatly parked atop a fire hydrant outside his home. The local daily called for his resignation. Based on just this information, what is the most likely outcome:

<<User Input>>
Mayor Fleese resigns.        [GO TO AAR1-2e1]
Mayor Fleese is convicted for drunk driving.      [GO TO AAR1-2e2]
Mayor Fleese is convicted of drunk driving and resigns.    [GO TO AAR1-2e3]
Mayor Fleese is convicted of drunk driving and stays in office.   [GO TO AAR1-2e4]
Mayor Fleese stays in office.        [GO TO AAR1-2e5]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2e1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese resigns," is unbiased!]

Good job -- I think you’ve got it! You avoided the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1] because you recognized that, by definition, it is more likely that Fleese will be convicted or resign than that he will do both. 

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2e2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese is convicted for drunk driving," is unbiased!]

Good job -- I think you’ve got it! You avoided the [em1]conjunction fallacy [/em1]because you recognized that, by definition, it is more likely that Fleese will be convicted or resign than that he will do both. 

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2e3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese is convicted of drunk driving and resigns."]

Having the mayor convicted of drunk driving and resigning is a pretty compelling narrative, which certainly makes it seem more likely than either the conviction or resignation happening alone -- however, this misconception is a result of the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1]. 

By definition,[em2] both events happening together is less likely than either one of the two events happening alone[/em2], regardless of what [em3]seems[/em3] more likely.

[GO TO AAR1-3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2e4
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese is convicted of drunk driving and stays in office."]

Having the mayor convicted of drunk driving and staying in office sounds like something a gregarious mayor might be able to get away with. However, believing that two events occurring together is more likely than either event happening alone -- just because it [em3]seems[/em3] more likely -- is a result of the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1]. 

By definition,[em2] both events happening together is less likely than either one of the two events happening alone.
[/em2]

[GO TO AAR1-3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-2e5
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese stays in office," is unbiased!]

Good job -- I think you’ve got it! You avoided the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1] because you recognized that, by definition, it is more likely that Fleese will stay in office [em3]or[/em3] be convicted of drunk driving than that he will do both.

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-3f
Fields.Dialogue Text:
When you encounter a situation where you are using your attitudes, perceptions, beliefs, or feelings to make judgments about a random sample of people, there is always the risk of committing [em1]projection bias[/em1]. Here's what you can do to minimize the pitfalls of projection bias: 

First, [em2]remember why we feel this way[/em2]. It's natural to use your own opinion and experience as a place to start when trying to figure how other people think and feel. Also, we tend to surround ourselves with people who share our values and beliefs. This makes it even more likely that we will overestimate the percentage of people who shares our values or beliefs, because [em2]we see our views overly represented in others[/em2] around us. 

Try to think about the opposite point of view -- might there be people who disagree with you? When estimating the percentage of people who agree with your opinion on an issue, try generating an initial estimate and then [em2]adjusting[/em2] [em4]downward[/em4] [em2]to account for all the people who disagree with you[/em2]. The percentage of people who agree with your opinion is probably lower than you think!

[GO TO AAR1-3g]

Remember: when estimating the percentage of people who agree with your views, [em2]imagine ALL of the people out there who hold a different opinion[/em2], and adjust your estimate accordingly. The percentage of people who agree with you is probably lower than you think!

Here’s the key: when estimating the percentage of people who agree with your views, [em2]imagine ALL of the people out there who hold a different opinion[/em2], and adjust your estimate accordingly to avoid [em1]projection bias[/em1]. The percentage of people who agree with you is probably lower than you think!

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-3i1]

Fields.Title: AAR1-3h3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your estimate: <<print $nanny>>%. Unbiased!"]

GREAT WORK! You underestimated the actual percentage of Americans who share your belief that the Government should limit the size of soft drinks in restaurants -- 69% -- and therefore avoided [em1]projection bias[/em1]. 

Perhaps you successfully used the bias mitigation strategy: when estimating the percentage of people who agree with your views,[em2] imagine ALL of the people out there who hold a different opinion[/em2], and adjust your estimate accordingly! The percentage of people who agree with you is probably lower than you think!

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-4]

Fields.Title: AAR1-3i1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
When you run into one of these challenges, [em2]try to avoid solely relying on your own feelings and attitudes to estimate how others feel[/em2]. Instead, try to put yourself into someone else's shoes -- someone quite different from yourself -- and imagine their perspective. 

When are you most likely to be influenced by the [em1]projection bias[/em1]? In some cases, it may be when you have a strong opinion about an issue. Take global warming, for example -- many people (on both sides) feel very strongly about it. And when someone feels that their view is obviously correct, they may assume that many more people share it. 

Let's start by considering your own position. Do you believe that global warming is real? 

<<User Input
Yes
No>>

[IF YES GO TO AAR1-3j]
[IF NO GO TO AAR1-3k]

 <<else>>

     <<display "AAR1-3j3">>
      <<else>>

            <<display "AAR1-3j4">>

 <<endif>>
<<endif>>

If we carefully consider how others' opinions may differ from our own, we can push back against the [em1]projection bias[/em1] by [em2]avoiding a false consensus[/em2] with our own opinions, and that's what you've done here.

Fields.Title: AAR1-4
Fields.Dialogue Text:
There was a second case in which the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1] might influence your judgment in the game segment you just completed. This variety of bias resulting from the representativeness heuristic is called "[em1]base rate neglect[/em1]." When we commit base rate neglect, [em2]we neglect to think of how often an event occurs in general[/em2]. 

For example, do field goal kickers tend to make that field goal 9 times out of 10, or 1 time in 10? Instead, we tend to overemphasize the specific details of the instance we are considering -- like does the kicker seem nervous right now? Focusing on the player's nervousness on a particular day over and above the average performance of field goal kickers would be an example of the representativeness heuristic influencing your judgment. 

[PAGE BREAK]|

Here's an example from the game:

Remember the scene with Mike -- when he asked you about which gym Mary, the new tenant, would join?   

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

MIKE (CONT'D)
Hey, have you seen Mary? 12H? By Carl's place...?

|[ENCLIP]

Mike supplied a critical piece of information: about 70% of the building's tenants went to Rocky's gym. A smaller percentage did nothing. 10% belonged to Entropy, the upscale gym that was more like a spa. The statistical percentages are the base rate. Mary, and Mike's description of her, is the specific case. 

[GO TO AAR1-4a]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $fitness eq "Rocky_Gym">>
<<display "AAR1-4a1">>
<<else>>
<<if $fitness eq "Entropy Fitness">>
<<display "AAR1-4a2">>
<<else>>
<<display "AAR1-4a3">>
<<endif>>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR1-4a1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: You chose "<<print $fitness>>."]

Nice job! Even though Mary may have seemed to resemble or "represent" the qualities of people who went to Entropy -- classy, cultured, stylish -- [em2]you paid attention to the base rate[/em2]. The clear majority of tenants ([em2]70%[/em2]) belong to Rocky's. In terms of probability, it's more likely that Mary will go there too. 

When categorizing someone, in order to avoid [em1]base rate neglect[/em1], consider the probability or base rate of each category that person might belong to. [em2]Avoid only relying on the representativeness of the specific case [/em2]you are making a judgment about.

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-4b]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4a2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: You chose "<<print $fitness>>."]

Mary's description -- classy, cultured, stylish -- may have seemed to resemble or "represent" the qualities of people who go to Entropy. However, your answer might not have taken the base rates into account: [em2]70%[/em2] of the tenants belong to Rocky's, whereas only [em2]10%[/em2] go to Entropy. In terms of probability, these base rates provide strong evidence that it's more likely that Mary will go to Rocky's. 

Just remember: in order to avoid [em1]base rate neglect[/em1] when categorizing a person or thing, consider the [em2]probability or base rate of each category that person might belong to[/em2], not just the representativeness of the specific case you are making a judgment about.

[GO TO AAR1-4b]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4a3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: You chose "<<print $fitness>>."]

Your answer might not have taken the base rates into account: [em2]70%[/em2] of the tenants belong to Rocky's, whereas only [em2]20%[/em2] consistently binge on Netflix and order Chinese food. In terms of probability, these base rates provide strong evidence that it's most likely that Mary goes to Rocky's gym. 

In order to avoid [em1]base rate neglect[/em1] when categorizing a person or thing, [em2]consider the probability or base rate of each category that person might belong to[/em2], not just how similar a person or thing is to a category. 

[GO TO AAR1-4b]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4b
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Try this one.

Meet Jennifer, a young American:

[img[file:///C:/Jennifer.PNG]]

Do you think it's more likely that she's a Satanist or a Christian?

<<User Input>>
[IF It's more likely that Jennifer is a Satanist.     GO TO AAR1-4b1]
[IF It's more likely that Jennifer is a Christian.     GO TO AAR1-4b2]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4b1
Fields.Menu Text: AAR1-4b1 - It's more likely that Jennifer is a Satanist.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<set $jennifer eq "wrong">>

Jennifer might resemble or "represent" what you think a Satanist would look like. But whenever you see the word "likely," it's a question of probability -- and remember, [em2]probability trumps similarity[/em2].

There are almost 80 times more Christians than Satanists in the United States. So, unless Jennifer has a tattoo reading "I am a Satanist" on her forehead, there's a much higher probability that Jennifer is a Christian than a Satanist.

[GO TO AAR1-4c]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4b2
Fields.Menu Text: AAR1-4b2 - It's more likely that Jennifer is a Christian.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<set $jennifer eq "right">>

Way to go! Even though Jennifer might resemble or "represent" what you think a Satanist would look like, you didn't commit [em1]base rate neglect[/em1]. There are almost 80 times more Christians than Satanists in the United States, so there is a far greater chance that she is a Christian. 

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-4c]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4c
Fields.Dialogue Text:
When you encounter a situation in which it's tempting to ignore base rates, as when the description of the specific person or event is particularly compelling, try the following: 

Remember that you're dealing with a probability estimate. [em2]Try not to think too much about the specific case [/em2] (e.g., Mary's or Jennifer's qualities), but [em2]do think about base rates[/em2]. Sometimes base rate information is provided, like the way Mike told you information about the fitness facilities. Sometimes it's common sense, like knowing there are more Christians than Satanists in the U.S. If the specific case strongly resembles a particular category, you're at high risk of committing [em1]base rate neglect[/em1]! 

[GO TO AAR1-4d]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4d
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $jennifer eq "right">>
<<display " AAR1-4e3">>
<<else>>
<<display "AAR1-4e">>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR1-4e
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Try one more:

Malik is an outgoing guy who likes wearing designer clothes, playing golf, having a whiskey after a steak dinner, and German automobiles. He works at Cryonics, a medical supply firm that employs 90 engineers and a team of 10 salespeople.

Is Malik more likely to be a salesperson or an engineer?

<<User Input>>
[IF Malik is more likely to be a salesperson.     GO TO AAR1-4e1]
[IF Malik is more likely to be an engineer.      GO TO AAR1-4e2]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4e3
Fields.Dialogue Text: Time to get back to our story. Terry's in custody, framed for a serious crime. It's up to you to investigate and find the evidence to exonerate her. Arthur Flaherty is devious... and ruthless. Watch your back!

Fields.Title: AAR1-4e1
Fields.Menu Text: AAR1-4e1 - Malik is more likely to be a salesperson.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: Malik is more likely to be a salesperson."]

Even though Malik may seem more like your concept of a salesperson and less like an engineer, [em2]90%[/em2] of the workforce at Cryonics is made up of engineers while only [em2]10%[/em2] are salespeople. Your answer might have demonstrated [em1]base rate neglect[/em1]. 

Just remember: if it's a question of probability (look for the word "likely"), [em2]probability is the most important consideration[/em2] -- not the similarity of the specific case to a given category.

[GO TO AAR1-4e3]

Fields.Title: AAR1-4e2
Fields.Menu Text: AAR1-4e2 - Malik is more likely to be an engineer.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: Malik is more likely to be an engineer."]

That's the ticket -- great job! Even though Malik may seem more like a salesperson and less like an engineer, you avoided [em1]base rate neglect[/em1] by going with the base rates ([em2]90%[/em2] engineers vs. [em2]10%[/em2] salespeople) instead of focusing on Malik’s similarity to your concept of a salesperson.

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR1-4e3]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
When you arrived at Thunderjaw Capital, the receptionist asked you about a stock she was considering.

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]|

MEGUMI
Uhm...listen. 
[Sly smile.]
MEGUMI (CONT'D)
I do a little investing of my own. I realize you must get asked this kind of thing ALL the time. But... could I get your opinion on Leisotech?

[ENDCLIP]|

This situation was designed to introduce you to a bias called the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1] that results from relying on the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1]. This type of representativeness heuristic involves not judgments about people or things, but about random sequences, such as coin flips. We often forget that random events can be independent. 

If you've ever watched a roulette wheel at a casino, for example, and the ball lands on red 5 times in a row, you might think that it should land on black on the next spin -- but the chances of getting red or black on the next spin never change, and are always independent of what has come before. Same goes for coin flips -- assuming you're flipping a fair coin, whether you flipped heads 1 time or 10 in the past, it's just as likely to come up heads as it is likely to come up tails on the next flip: 50%. [em2]Believing that an outcome in a random sequence of independent events is due for a change is a result of the gambler’s fallacy.[/em2] 

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Interestingly, stock movements can also be considered random. Because the market adjusts almost immediately to any factors affecting stock price, it is almost impossible (without insider information) to predict whether a stock will go up, down, or stay the same on a [em3]given day[/em3]. A set of previous increases doesn't give a stock "momentum" that makes a future increase more likely, nor does it predict that it must go down. 

<<if $price eq 57>>
<<display "AAR2-1a1">>
<<else>>
<<if $price eq 55.5>>
<<display "AAR2-1a2">>
<<if $price eq "unbiased">>
<<display "AAR2-1a3">>
<<else>>
<<if $price eq 54>>
<<display "AAR2-1a4">>
<<else>>
<<endif>>
<<endif>>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR2-1a1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: The price tomorrow is more likely to go to 57."]

Your answer stated that the stock would go up the following day. Seeing that the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, perhaps you thought it was due for an up-tick. 

This tendency, a belief that an outcome is due for a change, is a bias resulting from the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Stocks, like roulette wheels, have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same on any given day.

[GO TO AAR2-1b]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1a2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: The price tomorrow is more likely to go to 55.5."]

Your answer stated that the stock would go up the following day. Seeing that the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, perhaps you thought it was due for an up-tick. 

This tendency, a belief that an outcome is due for a change, is a bias resulting from the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Stocks, like roulette wheels, have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same on any given day.

[GO TO AAR2-1b]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1a3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: The price tomorrow is equally likely to go to 54 as 56.5."]

You thought that the stock had an equal chance of going up or down. In this response, you did not exhibit the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Well done!! You didn't fall into the trap of thinking that, since the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, it was due for an up-tick, or that it would keep dropping. Stocks, like roulette wheels, have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same on any given day.

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR2-1b]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1a4
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: The price tomorrow is more likely to go to 54."]

You answered that the stock would close at 54 the following day. Seeing that the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, perhaps you thought it would continue its trend. 

If you had thought the price trend was due for a change and would go up the next day, you would have committed the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1] -- which you didn’t, so great job! However, your answer that the stock would close at 54 the following day was not more likely than an outcome that had an equal chance of going up or down. Keep in mind that random events -- like stock prices on a given day -- have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same.

[GO TO AAR2-1b]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1b
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Think about this example: 

Let's say you're standing at the door of a car factory that is continually producing silver and white cars in equal numbers over time. The cars are painted and completed in a totally random sequence -- you don't know which color car is rolling off the assembly line and out the door next. 

While you're standing at the factory exit, you see the following sequence of cars roll out: silver, white, white, white, white. What color do you think the next car will be?

[IF PLAYER CHOICE: Silver       GO TO AAR2-1b1]
[IF PLAYER CHOICE: White       GO TO AAR2-1b2]
[IF PLAYER CHOICE: It is equally likely that the car will be white or silver. GO TO AAR2-1b3]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1b1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<set $car = "silver">>

Not quite. Remember: the sequence of cars is [em3]totally random[/em3]. That means that whatever happened before will not affect what happens next. If I flip a coin and it comes up heads 10 times in a row, the next toss still has an equal chance of being heads or tails. It's just the way probability works. The fact that it feels like it should come up tails doesn't matter. 

[GO TO AAR2-1c]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1b2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<set $car = "white">>

Not quite. Remember: the sequence of cars is [em2]totally random[/em2]. That means that whatever happened before will not affect what happens next. If I flip a coin and it comes up heads 10 times in a row, the next toss still has an equal chance of being heads or tails. It's just the way probability works.

[GO TO AAR2-1c]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1b3
Fields.Menu Text: AAR2-1b3 - It is equally likely that the car will be white or silver.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
AAR2-1b3
<<set $car = "It is equally likely that the car will be white or silver.">>

Nicely done! If the outcome is random, then whatever happened in the past will [em3]not [/em3]influence the next trial. You avoided the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]! It is equally likely that a white or a silver car will come out next.

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR2-2]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1c
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Try this one:

You're in a hospital maternity waiting room with your friend who is pacing a track into the linoleum as he anxiously awaits the arrival of his first born child. He's rethinking the wisdom of keeping the baby's sex a "surprise." You know that the birth rate in this hospital is exactly even: 50% boys and 50% girls. 

In the two hours you've been waiting, the ward nurses have come in six times to announce the arrival of a new baby. You and your friend have overheard the news. In every case, the nurses have announced the arrival of a girl. A moment later, a nurse comes out and finds your friend. Do you think she will report: 

[IF The arrival of a girl        GO TO AAR2-1c1]
[IF The arrival of a boy        GO TO AAR2-1c2]
[IF There is an equal chance of the nurse reporting the arrival of a boy or a girl. GO TO AAR2-1c3]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1c1
Fields.Menu Text: AAR2-1c1 - The arrival of a girl
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Your answer suggests that you might have thought that the streak of girls would continue. Remember the car factory? Equal chance of getting a silver car as a white car. Same thing here: equal chance of getting a boy as a girl. 

When we're dealing with random events -- coin tosses, roulette spins, babies born, cars painted -- whatever happened last time, and the time before, and the time before that [em2]do not make any difference for the next outcome[/em2]. To avoid the [em1]gambler’s fallacy[/em1], remember that random is random!

[GO TO AAR2-2]

Fields.Title: AAR2-1c2
Fields.Menu Text: AAR2-1c2 - The arrival of a boy
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Your answer indicates that you might have thought that because there was a run of girls, it was time for a boy. Remember the car factory? Equal chance of getting a silver car as a white car. Same thing here: equal chance of getting a boy as a girl. 

When we're dealing with random events -- coin tosses, roulette spins, babies born, cars painted -- whatever happened last time, and the time before, and the time before that[em2] do not make any difference for the next outcome[/em2]. To avoid the [em1]gambler’s fallacy[/em1], remember that random is random!

[GO TO AAR2-2]

Fields.Title: AAR1-1c3
Fields.Menu Text: AAR1-1c3 - There is an equal chance of the nurse reporting the arrival of a boy or a girl.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
I think you've really got it! Just remember: if an event is truly random, it doesn't matter how it's turned out previously. Flip a coin, roll a die, spin the wheel: [em2]what happened in the past will not affect what happens the next time[/em2]. 

When people feel like it's "due for a change," they’re exhibiting the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Won't work in Vegas, either!

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR2-2]

Fields.Title: AAR2-2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
So...once you got past the enterprising receptionist and the snooty assistant at Thunderjaw, you met an extremely smug executive, Barola. Since he was used to visitors being impressed with the view, he had a pop quiz ready --

[VIDEOCLIP - Game.]

BAROLA
(re: the view)
Never gets old, am I right? NYC: center of the universe...? Well, maybe once upon a time. Y'know how many cities have populations larger than New York's? Think it's more or less than ten cities...?

[ENDCLIP]

[TITLE: "You chose <<print $city>>."

Next, Barola asked you about the record length of a marlin. Do you remember how we talked about [em2]anchors -- values that can affect your numerical judgments[/em2]  and the fact that they can come from a number of places such as your friends, your boss, or your own personal knowledge? In this case, Barola provided you with an anchor -- the number 10. Even though the number 10 came from his question about the number of cities with populations larger than New York, so it was completely irrelevant to your estimate of the length of the longest marlin, this irrelevant anchor could still have influenced your judgment. In your case --

<<if $marlin gt 17>>
 <<display "AAR2-2a">>
<<else>>
 <<if $marlin eq 17>>
  <<display "AAR2-2b">>
 <<else>>
  <<if $marlin gt 15.2>>
   <<display "AAR2-2c1">>
  <<else>>
   <<display "AAR2-2c">>
  <<endif>>
 <<endif>>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR2-2a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your estimate: <<print $marlin>> feet. Unbiased!"]

-- although your estimate was not quite right, it appears that you weren’t biased by the anchor of 10, since the actual record is 17 feet. Congratulations!

Perhaps you noticed the anchor, guessed that the longest marlin was greater than 10 feet in length, made an initial estimate of its length, and then [em2]revised your first estimate even higher to avoid[/em2] [em1]anchoring bias[/em1]. Great job!!

[FIREWORKS]

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

To avoid [em1]anchoring bias[/em1], keep in mind: 

1. [em2]Be aware[/em2] that the information you just considered can influence subsequent judgments, whether it is relevant or not.

2. Don't passively accept your first guess. [em2]Make a deliberate adjustment AWAY from the anchor.[/em2] If you think the true value is higher than the anchor, revise your first estimate and go higher. If you think the true value is lower than the anchor, revise your first estimate and go lower. Bottom line: don't stop at your first guess! [em2]Consider additional information[/em2] that might be relevant to your estimate.

[GO TO AAR2-2d]

Fields.Title: AAR2-2b
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your estimate: <<print $marlin>> feet. Unbiased!"]

-- your estimate of 17 feet was not biased… in fact, it was dead-on! Congratulations!! You did not appear to be biased by the anchor of 10 that Barola had previously provided to you. 

Perhaps you noticed the anchor, guessed that the longest marlin was greater than 10 feet in length, made an initial estimate of its length, and then [em2]revised your first estimate even higher to avoid [/em2][em1]anchoring bias[/em1]. Great job!!

[FIREWORKS]

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

To avoid [em1]anchoring bias[/em1], keep in mind: 

1. [em2]Be aware [/em2]that the information you just considered can influence subsequent judgments, whether it is relevant or not. 

2. Don't passively accept your first guess. [em2]Make a deliberate adjustment AWAY from the anchor[/em2]. If you think the true value is higher than the anchor, revise your first estimate and go higher. If you think the true value is lower than the anchor, revise your first estimate and go lower. [em2]Consider additional information [/em2]that might be relevant to your estimate as well.

[GO TO AAR2-2d]

-- your estimate was very close to the actual record of 17 feet. Good job!

-- your estimate was less than the actual record of 17 feet, so it might have been impacted by the anchor of 10. 

People’s judgments may be affected by anchors in a number of different ways: they may not consciously acknowledge the anchor, or they may forget about the ways to mitigate [em1]anchoring bias[/em1]. Those aware of the strategies for anchoring bias mitigation may not adjust far enough away from the anchor.

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Fields.Title: AAR2-2-Focalism
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Another kind of [em1]anchoring bias[/em1] that affects our everyday predictions is [em1]focalism[/em1]. Focalism occurs when we make a judgment about the impact of an event on something in the future, [em1]and neglect to consider and take into account all the other things[/em1] that will also influence the future event. 

For example, if someone asks how happy you would be next year if you moved to Hawaii, you might commit focalism if you only based your prediction on where you were moving.

[HAWAII GRAPHIC "LIVING HERE"]

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Those who would be ecstatic to move to Hawaii might be picturing their new life in paradise, where they can relax on sunny beaches all day. However, this [em2]one-sided view fails to consider other things [/em2]that would likely influence their feelings about the move. Separation from family and friends back home, finding a new job, and the increased cost of living are examples of some not-so-fun aspects of living in Hawaii.

[HAWAII GRAPHIC "FAMILY FRIENDS LIVING HERE JOB BILLS]

To avoid [em1]focalism[/em1] when making a judgment about how we might feel in a certain situation, [em2]keep in mind that a single event is unlikely to be the[/em2] [em4]only[/em4] [em2]factor determining a future state[/em2]. Lots of other things might influence it as well, and ignoring them may introduce focalism into your judgment.

[GO TO AAR 2-3]

Fields.Title: AAR2-3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Back in Barola's office, he made no secret of his passion for big game fishing. He asked you for your take on hunting for sport:

|[VIDEOCLIP - game.]

BAROLA
Of course -- the sport isn't for everyone. I mean: live and let live, right? They are great and noble creatures -- do you think it's wrong to hunt animals for sport?

[ENDCLIP]|

You chose values to represent how you and the "average person" feel about hunting for sport. You had a scale of 1 to 7, where "1" meant you think it's completely wrong to hunt animals for sport, "4" meant you have no opinion on the issue, and "7" meant you think it's totally OK. 

This was another [em1]projection bias[/em1] challenge. Once again, [em2]people are more likely to see traits in others that they see in themselves[/em2]. So, if you think hunting for sport is OK, projection bias would lead you to think that others feel the same way.

[GO TO AAR2-3a]

Fields.Title: AAR2-3a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $ihunt eq $ophunt>>
<<display "AAR2-3a1">>
<<else>>
<<if Math.abs($ihunt-$ophunt) lte 2>>
<<display "AAR2-3a2">>
<<else>>
<<display "AAR2-3a3">>
<<endif>>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR2-3a1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "On a scale of 1 to 7, you chose <<print $ihunt>> for your own opinion and <<print $ophunt>> for how the average person feels."]

Your answer indicates that you believe other people feel exactly the same as you do about hunting for sport. While many people attribute their own opinions to others when asked this type of question, rating others exactly the same as themselves may be a result of [em1]projection bias[/em1]. 

When you encounter a challenge that asks you to rank your attitudes or feelings about a topic, [em2]DO NOT assume that others share your view[/em2]. Revise your assessment of what others might think or feel about a topic to be further away from your own opinion than you initially estimate.

[GO TO AAR2-3b]

Fields.Title: AAR2-3a2
Fields.Dialogue Text:

While many people attribute their own opinions to others when asked this type of question, rating others as being overly similar to themselves may be a result of [em1]projection bias[/em1]. 

When you encounter a challenge that asks you to rank your attitudes or feelings about a topic, [em2]DO NOT assume that others share your view[/em2]. In most cases, it is helpful to revise your initial assessment of what others might think or feel about a topic to be further away from your own opinion than you initially estimate.

[GO TO AAR2-3b]

Fields.Title: AAR2-3a3
Fields.Dialogue Text:

Excellent work!! You avoided [em1]projection bias[/em1] by recognizing that other people may hold very different opinions than you do. Many people attribute their own opinions to others when asked this type of question, rating others as being overly similar to themselves. 

When you encounter a challenge that asks you to rate your attitudes or feelings about a topic, [em2]DO NOT assume that others share your view[/em2]. In most cases, it is helpful to revise your initial assessment of what others might think or feel about a topic to be further away from your own opinion than you initially estimate. 

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR2-3b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Wow, that was some serious blogging. And nice shelf technique, by the way. You'll be happy to know that Arthur Flaherty, after losing his appeals, his friends and all the cash the Government could find, has gone away for a l-o-o-o-o-n-g time. He claims to have found religion -- and particular comfort in needle point. Travis got off with a light sentence but lost more than his liberty. Terry most definitely is NOT standing by her man.

As you may have already guessed, there were some additional bias challenges woven into the finale of your adventure. Let's see how you did.

[PAGE BREAK]|

Remember the pallets with the figurines?

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

TERRY
Those are the shipments! We've got to check those boxes. They all look the same...there are only ten of the blue statue. Which palette should we check? We have to move fast!

[ENDCLIP]

There were 110 boxes altogether; 10 of the boxes contained the blue figurines like Terry received. They were randomly mixed with 100 boxes of horse models. The challenge was: which pallet load to check? The one with 98 pieces or the one with 12?

Let's see how you did.

[GO TO AAR3-1a]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $pallet eq 12>>
<<display "AAR3-1a1">>
<<else>>
<<display "AAR3-1a2">>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR3-1a1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Since you chose the pallet with 12 items on it, your answer might have been influenced by another version of the [em1]representativeness heuristic -- sample size neglect[/em1].

A larger sample -- in this case, the lot of 98 statues -- is more likely to be representative of the overall distribution of pieces. [em2]In a small sample, there is often more variability than in a larger one.[/em2] Although the small pallet might be quicker to search, there was a greater likelihood that it contained an uneven distribution of the blue statues you were looking for, and possibly none of the blue statues were in it at all! On the other hand, it is unlikely that there wouldn't be some in the big pile. 

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Statistically, your chances of actually finding a figurine are much better if you examine the larger pile. When given a choice between a smaller and a larger sample, [em2]the larger sample will almost always be a better representation of the average[/em2].

We exhibit [em1]sample size neglect[/em1] when we overestimate the extent to which small samples will resemble much larger samples or are overly confident in the validity of our conclusions based on small samples. 

[GO TO AAR3-1b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1a2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Since you chose the pallet with 98 items on it, you avoided another version of the [em1]representativeness heuristic -- sample size neglect[/em1]. Nice going! 

A larger sample -- in this case, the lot of 98 statues -- is more likely to be representative of the overall distribution of pieces. [em2]In a small sample, there is often more variability than in a larger one[/em2] -- thus, there was a greater likelihood that the small pallet contained an uneven distribution of the blue statues you were looking for, and possibly none of the blue statues were in it at all! It made sense to search the pallet with 98 boxes because there was a much higher chance that you'd find a blue figurine. 

[FIREWORKS]

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Statistically, your chances of actually finding a figurine are much better if you examine the larger pile. When given a choice between a smaller and a larger sample,[em2] the larger sample will almost always be a better representation of the average[/em2].

Generally, we exhibit [em1]sample size neglect[/em1] when we overestimate the extent to which small samples will resemble much larger samples or are overly confident in the validity of our conclusions based on small samples. 

[GO TO AAR3-1b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1b
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Try another one:

Goldilocks, after her early developmental experiences with bears, decided to open a retro-chic restaurant. One of the menu staples is porridge.

Through hard experience, she has learned that her customers are apt to complain about the temperature of the porridge, no matter what temperature she makes it. Certainly, she can relate. She has worked out a compromise: at 180 degrees, 50% of the people will complain and 50% will say that it's..."just right."  

On a quiet morning, she'll get about 6 guests in a 15 minute period. On a busy day, she'll get about 30. On which kind of day do you think she'll get [em2]more than 50%[/em2] of her customers complaining?

[PLAYER CHOICE On a busy day.         GO TO AAR3-1b1]
PLAYER CHOICE On a quiet day.         GO TO AAR3-1b2]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1b1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Hmmm... your answer might have been influenced by [em1]sample size neglect[/em1]. Let’s go over the logic of how to reach the correct answer.

The question was, "On which kind of day do you think Goldilocks will get [em2]more than 50%[/em2] of her customers complaining?" ... in other words, which sample is more likely [em4]not[/em4] to resemble the average?

Think about Goldilocks's 6 or so customers on a quiet day, 3 of which are usually grouchy. If she has just [em3]1 extra person[/em3] come in with a bad mood, her numbers (50% grumpy, 50% happy) get all messed up. On a busy day, 1 extra grumpy person in 30 wouldn't really move the needle. Bottom line: [em2]there's much greater potential for unusual results in a smaller sample[/em2]. 

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Here's how to avoid [em1]sample size neglect[/em1]:

When you're looking at a statistic, the larger sample will always come closer to the average. So whether it’s the pallet of boxes or Goldilocks's customers, bigger samples are more likely to be an accurate reflection of the overall population. [em2]Focus on larger samples over smaller samples[/em2], when possible!

[GO TO AAR3-1c]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1b2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Bravo! You were not taken in by [em1]sample size neglect[/em1]. You must have thought about Goldilocks's 6 or so customers on a quiet day, 3 of which are usually grouchy: if she has just 1 extra person come in with a bad mood, her numbers (50% grumpy, 50% happy) get all messed up. On a busy day, 1 extra grumpy person in 30 wouldn't really move the needle.

Bottom line: [em2]there's much greater potential for unusual results in a smaller sample[/em2]. 

[FIREWORKS]

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Just remember, to avoid [em1]sample size neglect[/em1]:

When you're looking at a statistic, the larger sample will always come closer to the average. So whether it’s the pallet of boxes or Goldilocks's customers, bigger samples are more likely to be an accurate reflection of the overall population.[em2] Focus on larger samples over smaller samples[/em2], when possible!

[GO TO AAR3-1c]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1c
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Try one more:

Harry and David have been fishing Lake Tlawotuha for years -- usually catching nothing. This year, they are quite excited that the US Department of Fish and Wildlife have stocked the lake with Triploid and Kokanee trout. They are, however, unclear about how many of each the Government put in the lake.

After the first day of fishing, Harry has a catch of 5 fish (a personal best), but David has a whopping 18 fish. Harry caught 3 Triploid and 2 Kokanee trout: 60% and 40%, respectively. David caught 14 Kokanee and 4 Triploid: 78% and 22% in favor of the Kokanee.

What do you think is more likely that the Government did:

[PLAYER CHOICE Stock the lake with 60% Triploid trout. GO TO AAR3-1c1]
[PLAYER CHOICE Stock the lake with 78% Kokanee trout. GO TO AAR3-1c2]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1c1
Fields.Menu Text: AAR3-1c1 - Stock the lake with 60% Triploid trout.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Your answer might have been affected by [em1]sample size neglect[/em1]. David had a larger sample (18 fish), so his numbers (78% Kokanee trout) are more likely to be representative of the actual composition of the fish population in the lake.

When you're looking at a statistic,[em2] the larger sample will always come closer to the average[/em2]. Smaller samples often have unusual quirks that throw off the numbers. Remember to go big!

[GO TO AAR3-2]

Fields.Title: AAR3-1c2
Fields.Menu Text: AAR3-1c2 - Stock the lake with 78% Kokanee trout.
Fields.Dialogue Text:
You definitely got it! GREAT JOB!! David had a larger sample (18 fish), so his numbers (78% Kokanee trout) are more likely to be representative of the actual composition of the fish population in the lake.

When you're looking at a statistic, [em2]the larger sample will always come closer to the average[/em2].

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR3-2]

Fields.Title: AAR3-2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
So...you probably remember when Arthur Flaherty started shooting --

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

[Terry is so startled she jostles a small part on the shelf which falls to the warehouse floor. Flaherty peers in our direction; the gun leaves Paliwal.]
FLAHERTY
What was that?!
(he roars)
GET OUT HERE NOW!
[Grantik sees his chance, races for the safety of dark recesses of the warehouse. BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM BOOM. Fire leaps from Flaherty's handgun. Grantik gasps, staggers, falls. Motionless.]

[ENDCLIP]|

-- and Terry's pretty bold decision to confront him.

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

TERRY
Sonuva -- 
(A thought.)
TERRY
Wait. How many shots did he fire...? Six. Yeah it was six!

[ENDCLIP]|

The challenge was to estimate how many bullets were in Flaherty's handgun when it was fully loaded.

And, yes: this was another [em1]anchoring bias[/em1] challenge, like the time people spend on Facebook or the size of the biggest marlin. This one was a little different: the anchor came from you. 

Most people might think of handguns that have 6 bullets, like the 19th century Colt revolvers. That knowledge then becomes a potential self-generated anchor that can bias your answer. As it turns out, a modern handgun like the Glock 17 accepts magazines of 17, 19, and 33 rounds. Let's see how you did.

[GO TO AAR3-2a]

Fields.Title: AAR3-2a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $gun lt 6>>
 <<display "AAR3-2a1">>
<<else>>
 <<if $gun eq 6>>
  <<display "AAR3-2a2">>
 <<else>>
  <<if $gun gt 17>>
   <<display "AAR3-2a3">>
  <<else>>
   <<if $gun eq 17>>
    <<display "AAR3-2a4">>
   <<else>>
    <<if $gun gte 15>>
     <<display "AAR3-2a5">>
    <<else>>
     <<display "AAR3-2a6">>
    <<endif>>
   <<endif>>
  <<endif>>
 <<endif>>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR3-2a1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "You thought his gun had a capacity of <<print $gun>> bullets."]

Not exactly. In fact, you seem to have guessed that Arthur had fewer bullets in his gun when it was fully loaded than he appeared to have shot. Interesting. This kind of handgun -- the Glock 17 -- most commonly accepts a 17 round magazine.

The key to avoiding [em1]anchoring bias[/em1] is to [em2]try to be aware of the anchor and adjust away from it[/em2]. Seek out additional information to aid your decision-making process when possible, as well. Don't simply accept the first answer that comes to mind!

[GO TO AAR3-2b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-2a2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "You thought his gun had a capacity of <<print $gun>> bullets."]

Your answer is equivalent to the anchor of 6 bullets. It is possible that your estimate was impacted by [em1]anchoring bias[/em1]. Arthur’s handgun -- the Glock 17 -- most commonly accepts a 17 round magazine.

The key with this kind of anchoring is to[em2] try to be aware of the anchor and adjust away from it[/em2]. Seek out additional information to aid your decision-making process when possible, as well. Don't simply accept the first answer that comes to mind.

[GO TO AAR3-2b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-2a3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "You thought his gun had a capacity of <<print $gun>> bullets. Unbiased!"]

That's impressive! Arthur’s handgun -- the Glock 17 -- most commonly accepts a 17 round magazine. You avoided the [em1]anchoring bias[/em1]!

Fields.Title: AAR3-3
Fields.Dialogue Text:
The final bias challenge in the game arose from Travis's quandary over his upcoming legal woes.

[VIDEOCLIP - Game]

TERRY
(enjoying his discomfort)
From the piece I did on New York prosecutors, the odds are fifty-fifty for conviction in New York. And you'll probably face four consecutive trials, given how much publicity this is going to generate.

[ENDCLIP]|

This game situation was designed to highlight another bias that results from relying on the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1], the [em1]perception of randomness[/em1]: some outcomes seem like they are more random than others that are equally random. 

We often expect random sequences to resemble a certain mental model of randomness -- to "look" random. We might think that some patterns look or "feel" random -- like an alternating pattern of conviction and acquittal -- and other patterns look or "feel" less random -- like a string of convictions and then an acquittal. [em2]People tend to think that random sequences have a lot of alternations, to a greater extent than you should actually expect for chance events.[/em2]

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

Here, take a look for yourself: [img[file:///C:/HeadsTails.JPG]]. These are all the possible sequences of coin tosses, and each of these sequences is equally likely, happening 1/8th of the time. But Sequences 1 and 8 look very non-random, and so, due to this bias, we expect them to be less common. Sequence 3, on the other hand, just looks more like a typical random sequence, and so it [em3]feels [/em3]like it should somehow be more likely to occur. 

In short, we may erroneously think that a pattern that looks or "feels" random is more likely to occur. However we may feel things should turn out, the truth is that, [em2]for any small sample, all patterns and outcomes are equally possible[/em2]. 

[GO TO AAR3-3a]

Fields.Title: AAR3-3a
Fields.Dialogue Text:
<<if $trial neq "All outcomes are equally likely">>
<<display "AAR3-3a1">>
<<else>>
<<display "AAR3-3a2">>
<<endif>>

Fields.Title: AAR3-3a1
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: <<print $trial>>.]

The thing to remember about this kind of bias challenge is that you're not looking for the appearance of "randomness." Toss a coin 3 times and 3 heads in a row will not violate any law of chance. It's not less random than heads-tails-heads.

[GO TO AAR3-3b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-3a2
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer: <<print $trial>>was not biased!]

Well played! 

The thing to remember about this kind of bias challenge is that you're not looking for the appearance of "randomness." Toss a coin 3 times and 3 heads in a row will not violate any law of chance. It's not less random than heads-tails-heads. Any particular sequence of heads and tails is equally possible.

[FIREWORKS]

[GO TO AAR3-3b]

Fields.Title: AAR3-3b
Fields.Dialogue Text:
Let's try one more:

Rosie and Gil love to picnic with their children under the final approach to Metropolis Airport. There are two carriers: Intercontinental (I) and Global (G). Each has an equal number of flights.

Which is the more likely sequence of landing aircraft?

[PLAYER CHOICE I-G-G-I-G-I         GO TO AAR3-3b1]
[PLAYER CHOICE I-I-I-I-G-I          GO TO AAR3-3b2]
[PLAYER CHOICE Equally likely         GO TO AAR3-3b3]

Fields.Title: AAR3-3b4
Fields.Dialogue Text:
[TITLE: "Your answer:  "[var=planes]" ]

Actually, all outcomes are equally likely. Remember that in any small sample, [em2]all sequences are possible and have equal probability[/em2]. 

[PAGE BREAK – NEXT BUTTON]|

[VIDEOCLIP - Closing video]

This concludes your adventure today, both with Terry and with these various forms of cognitive biases. 

[A MOVING COLLAGE of the striking imagery...Jennifer, the Venn diagram, the examples, scenes from the game etc.]

Just remember:

We explored three kinds of biases today:

1. Anchoring: Think of additional information and consciously adjust away from the anchor. Don't get stuck on your first guess. 
2. Representativeness: Keep in mind that similarity is not probability. The conjunction of two events is less likely than either one event. Larger samples tend to be more accurate than smaller samples, and are more informative than single cases. 
3. Projection: Remember that we tend to overestimate how many other people share our beliefs, preferences, and feelings.

These biases are deeply ingrained in us -- but with knowledge and practice, we can avoid the pitfalls that they sometimes bring.

Thank you for playing!
